column4: Bigger problem: apparently GRUB is no longer installed, though I know it has to be because I just booted from it a few hours ago. grub --version tells me that grub isn't installed.
grub2 doesn't have a "grub" command. Try "grub-install --version".
And whatever you do, do *not* apt-get install grub (as that will remove grub2 and install grub legacy).
does grub2 no longer have a grub.conf or menu.lst?
Change grub2 settings in /etc/default/grub, then update the /boot/grub/grub.cfg by running "sudo update-grub".
I found the /etc/default/grub file, tried sudo grub-mkconfig or some such instead of sudo update-grub.
sudo update-grub is the same as "sudo grub-mkconfig -o /boot/grub/grub.cfg".
I'm at a remote location so I don't want to muck with it and restart yet, but I'll check it out later this afternoon.
I didn't pass an output file argument earlier, I wonder where that conf file got written...
Well, my office is unlocked at the remote location, I might go over the documentation REALLY WELL and just have someone go in and fix it if it breaks :)
speaking of which, thanks for the help :)
